Playlists

Published on October 26, 2025 | By JW

My earliest Spotify playlist was constructed in 2013. Over the past dozen years, I have curated and refined several collections of songs for various moods and purposes. Here I will explore some of my personal favorites.

Christian Worship

"Soli Deo Gloria" was one of my early forays into constructing a playlist showcasing the duality of catechism and faith—the twin swords of knowledge and conviction—in musical form. It has thereafter become something of a period piece; it may still be an enjoyable listen but no longer meets my standards for vision and rigorous design. Nevertheless, without it, we would not have "Sola Gratia," my attempt at formulating a playlist fit for enjoying and designing accessible personal and corporate worship sets. This playlist is meant to be listened in order, as themes—both lyrical and musical—from one song may continue into the next. Contiguous portions of this playlist may be adapted into worship sets with some creative splicing. And, finally, the latest installment, whose construction continues, is "Solus Christus." The vision for this collection is to comprehensively recount every worship song with which I am familiar—an ambitious goal that remains in the works.

Classical

"Heard melodies are sweet, but those unheard / Are sweeter; therefore, ye soft pipes, play on."

Postscript

Interested in analyzing your own playlists? Here's the simple Python script I wrote that utilizes the Spotify API to export the tracklist of any public or private playlist you own. 


import spotipy
from spotipy.oauth2 import SpotifyOAuth

# ====== CONFIGURATION ======
SPOTIFY_CLIENT_ID = "your_client_id"
SPOTIFY_CLIENT_SECRET = "your_client_secret"
SPOTIFY_REDIRECT_URI = "http://127.0.0.1:8000/callback"
PLAYLIST_ID = "spotify:playlist:your_playlist_id"  # Can be URI or ID
OUTPUT_FILE = "playlist.txt"

# Scope for reading private playlists
scope = "playlist-read-private"

# ====== AUTHENTICATION ======
sp = spotipy.Spotify(auth_manager=SpotifyOAuth(client_id=SPOTIFY_CLIENT_ID,
                                               client_secret=SPOTIFY_CLIENT_SECRET,
                                               redirect_uri=SPOTIFY_REDIRECT_URI,
                                               scope=scope))

# ====== FUNCTION TO GET ALL TRACKS ======
def get_all_tracks(playlist_id):
    tracks = []
    results = sp.playlist_items(playlist_id, limit=100)
    tracks.extend(results['items'])
    
    while results['next']:
        results = sp.next(results)
        tracks.extend(results['items'])
    
    return tracks

# ====== EXPORT PLAYLIST ======
all_tracks = get_all_tracks(PLAYLIST_ID)

with open(OUTPUT_FILE, "w", encoding="utf-8") as f:
    for item in all_tracks:
        track = item['track']
        artists = ", ".join([artist['name'] for artist in track['artists']])
        line = f"{artists} – {track['name']}\n"
        f.write(line)

print(f"Playlist exported to {OUTPUT_FILE} ({len(all_tracks)} tracks)")

  1. Install Spotipy (if you haven’t already):
    2. pip install spotipy
  2. Create a Spotify Developer App: https://developer.spotify.com/dashboard
    • Get your Client ID and Client Secret.
  3. Replace the placeholders in the script:
    • your_client_id → your app’s Client ID
    • your_client_secret → your app’s Client Secret
    • your_playlist_id → Spotify playlist URI (like spotify:playlist:37i9dQZF1DXcBWIGoYBM5M) or just the ID string.
  4. Run the script:
    5. python export_spotify_playlist.py
  5. Check playlist.txt — each line will be:
    6. Artist 1, Artist 2 – Song Title
